case_name: Central Talkies Ltd., Kanpur and Lala Ram Narain Garg v. Babu Dwarka Prasad

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 374 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 21, 1955 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 251 of 1954 rising out of the judgment and decree dated May 24, 1954, of the Civil Judge, Kanpur, in Suit No. 35 of 1949. V. Viswanatha Sastri, G. S. Pathak and Naunit Lal for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 21, 1955 of Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 251 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 21, 1955 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 251 of 1954 rising out of the judgment and decree dated May 24, 1954, of the Civil Judge, Kanpur, in Suit No. 35 of 1949.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment arose from judgment dated May 24, 1954 of Civil Judge, Kanpur in Suit No. 35 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: rising out of the judgment and decree dated May 24, 1954, of the Civil Judge, Kanpur, in Suit No. 35 of 1949. V. Viswanatha Sastri, G. S. Pathak and Naunit Lal for the appellant. C. Chatterjee, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji and P. L. Vohra, for the respondent. 1961. January 16.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court reversed trial court decision and decreed suit for ejectment against appellants and awarded damages at Rs. 593-12-0 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, reversing the decision of the trial Court, decreed the present suit for ejectment against the appellants, and also awarded damages to the plaintiff- respondent at the rate of Rs. 593-12-0 per month.

facts.text: Suit filed by respondent Babu Dwarka Prasad against appellants Central Talkies Ltd., Kanpur and Lala Ram Narain Garg, Managing Director.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed by the respondent,, Babu Dwarka Prasad, against the appellants, Central Talkies Ltd., Kanpur, and Lala Ram Narain Garg, the Managing Director of the Company.

facts.text: Dwarka Prasad was sole owner of plot of land No.73/22 old No. 73/28 situated in Collector gunj, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The facts, briefly stated, are as follows Dwarka Prasad was the sole owner of a plot of land No.73/22  old No. 73/28  situated in Collector gunj, Kanpur.

facts.text: In 1933 an agreement of lease was executed by five persons in favour of Lala Rameshwardas, predecessor-in-title of Babu Dwarka Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: In 1933 an agreement of lease was executed by five persons in favour of Lala Rameshwardas, the predecessor-in-title of Babu Dwarka Prasad, by which the five lessees took over on lease a hall and other company structions, which the lessor agreed to build at a companyt of Rs. 16,000/- within four months.

facts.text: Lease agreement: lessor to build hall and constructions at cost of Rs. 16,000 within four months.

anchor.surface_text: by which the five lessees took over on lease a hall and other company structions, which the lessor agreed to build at a companyt of Rs. 16,000/- within four months. It was agreed that, if the lessor was required to spend an amount in excess of Rs. 16,000/-, he would be entitled to interest at the rate of 12 annas per cent. per month from the second party till the end of tenancy.

facts.text: Tenancy was month to month for 5 years in first instance.

anchor.surface_text: The tenancy was from month to month, and the period of the tenancy was fixed at 5 years in the first instance. This tenancy companytinued with variations in the amount of rent till the year 1946,

facts.text: On January 15, 1946, Dwarka Prasad sent letter to defendants that lease expires February 28, 1946, vacate by that date.

anchor.surface_text: and on January 15, 1946, Dwarka Prasad sent a letter to the defendants that the period of lease was to expire on February 28, 1946, and that the Central Talkies Ltd. should vacate the premises by that date,

facts.text: Defendants did not vacate the premises.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants did number vacate the premises, and a suit for ejectment was filed against the Central Talkies Ltd.

facts.text: Suit for ejectment filed against Central Talkies Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: and a suit for ejectment was filed against the Central Talkies Ltd.During the pendency of that suit, the United Provinces  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  referred to in the judgment as the Eviction Act , came into force.

facts.text: United Provinces Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947 came into force during pendency of first suit.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of that suit, the United Provinces  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947  referred to in the judgment as the Eviction Act , came into force. Under s. 3 of the Eviction Act, permission of the District Magistrate was required to file in any Civil Court a suit for the eviction of a tenant, except on grounds which were enumerated in the section.

facts.text: First suit withdrawn because filed on ground not enumerated in s.3 of Eviction Act.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, that suit was filed on a ground which was number enumerated in the section, and Dwarka Prasad withdrew it.

facts.text: Dwarka Prasad applied to District Magistrate for permission to eject Central Talkies Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: He then applied to the District Magistrate for permission to eject the Central Talkies Ltd., from the premises, and permission was granted by the Additional District Magistrate  Rural Area  on July 7, 1948.

facts.text: Permission granted by Additional District Magistrate Rural Area on July 7, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and permission was granted by the Additional District Magistrate  Rural Area  on July 7, 1948. It is number necessary to state the pleas which were taken by the defendants in the newly filed suit,

facts.text: District Magistrate transferred case to Mr. Hadi Hasan, Additional District Magistrate, who sent it back asking for transfer because approached by defendants.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that, at first, the application for permission was made over by the District Magis. trate to Mr. Hadi Hasan, who was also an Additional District Magistrate but the latter sent the case back to the District Magistrate asking for a transfer, because he had been approached on behalf of the defendants.

facts.text: District Magistrate ordered on February 11, 1948: Transferred to Additional District Magistrate R.A. for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate thereafter passed an order on February 11, 1948, to the following effect Transferred to Additional District Magistrate  R.A.  for disposal.

facts.text: Application disposed by Mr. Brijpal Singh Seth, Additional District Magistrate Rural Area, on July 7, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The application for permission was disposed of by Mr. Brijpal Singh Seth, Additional District Magistrate  Rural Area , on July 7, 1948.

facts.text: Mr. Brijpal Singh Seth appointed Additional District Magistrate by Notification No. 3400/11-276-48 dated May 22, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: This Officer, who was previously a City Magistrate, Kanpur, was appointed an Additional District Magistrate by Notification No. 3400/11-276-48 dated May 22, 1948.

facts.text: Notification appointed Shri Brijpal Singh Seth as Additional District Magistrate with all powers of District Magistrate under CrPC and other laws.

anchor.surface_text: The material portion of this Notification read as follows With effect from the date on which he takes over charge Shri Brijpal Singh Seth, City Magistrate, Kanpur, is appointed vice Shri Sheo Ramdas Saksena-  a  under sub-section  2  of section 10 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  Act V of 1898 , to be an Additional District Magistrate of Kanpur District, with jurisdiction extending over the whole of the said district and with all the powers of a District Magistrate under the said Code and under any other law for the time being in force

facts.text: Appellants contended suit incompetent due to lack of proper permission under s.3 Eviction Act.

anchor.surface_text: because the only point argued before us was that the suit was incompetent, because permission of the District Magistrate as required by s. 3 had number been obtained.

facts.text: Appellants abandoned argument on invalidity of notice.

anchor.surface_text: At first, the appellants wished to raise a question as to the invalidity of the numberice but during the companyrse of the arguments, that ground was expressly abandoned.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Divisional Bench held suit competent.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench of the High Court held that the suit was companypetent.

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J. held Additional DM empowered under s.10(2) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Raghubar Dayal, J. held that the Additional District Magistrate, who granted permission, was empowered by the Provincial Government under s. 10 2  of the Code of Criminal Procedure to exercise all the powers of a District Magistrate under the Code and all the laws for the time being in force, and the requirements of s. 3 were companyplied with.
under Art. 133 1  b  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the suit was incompetent because permission of the District Magistrate as required by s. 3 of the Eviction Act had not been obtained

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to state the pleas which were taken by the defendants in the newly filed suit, because the only point argued before us was that the suit was incompetent, because permission of the District Magistrate as required by s. 3 had not been obtained.

issues.text: Whether the Additional District Magistrate empowered by the Provincial Government under s. 10(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure to exercise all powers of a District Magistrate under the Code and all other laws was competent to grant permission under s. 3 of the Eviction Act

anchor.surface_text: Raghubar Dayal, J. held that the Additional District Magistrate, who granted permission, was empowered by the Provincial Government under s. 10 2  of the Code of Criminal Procedure to exercise all the powers of a District Magistrate under the Code and all the laws for the time being in force, and the requirements of s. 3 were complied with.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate authorised the Additional District Magistrate to perform his functions under the Eviction Act by transferring the case to him, thereby including him in the definition of District Magistrate under s. 2(d)

anchor.surface_text: Brij Mohan Lal, J. came to the conclusion that the District Magistrate by transferring the case to the Additional District Magistrate  Rural Area  had authorised him to perform his functions under the Act in this behalf and that the Additional District Magistrate, being thus included in the definition of District Magistrate under s. 2 d , was competent to grant the permission.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate mentioned in s. 3 of the Eviction Act was a persona designata such that only he or an officer authorised by him could grant permission

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the appellants was that the District Magistrate mentioned in s. 3 was a persona designata, and that either he or an officer authorised by him, to perform his functions could grant permission.

issues.text: Whether s. 10(2) of the CrPC applies to the special or local law being the Eviction Act in view of s. 1(2) of the CrPC providing that nothing affects special or local laws absent specific provision to the contrary

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants contended that the definition of District Magistrate clearly showed that in addition to the District Magistrate, only an officer specially authorised by him could act under the Eviction Act, and he referred to sub-s.  2  of s. 1 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which provided It extends to the whole of British India but, in the absence of any specific provision to the contrary, nothing herein contained shall affect any special or local law

arguments.claim: Notification under s.10(2) CrPC invested Additional DM with all powers of DM under CrPC and any other law, making him competent without further authorization

anchor.surface_text: The material portion of this Notification read as follows With effect from the date on which he takes over charge Shri Brijpal Singh Seth, City Magistrate, Kanpur, is appointed vice Shri Sheo Ramdas Saksena-  a  under sub-section  2  of section 10 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  Act V of 1898 , to be an Additional District Magistrate of Kanpur District, with jurisdiction extending over the whole of the said district and with all the powers of a District Magistrate under the said Code and under any other law for the time being in force

arguments.claim: s.10(2) CrPC applies to Eviction Act as it provides specific provision contrary to s.1(2) CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The argument overlooks the words in the absence of any specific provision to the contrary , and because there is in the Code of Criminal Procedure such a provision in s. 10 2 , sub-s.  2  of s. 1 is excluded, and an Additional District Magistrate must be regarded as possessing the powers under any other law including the Eviction Act.

arguments.claim: Definition in s.2(d) creates officers exercising DM powers by office upon authorization; not persona designata

anchor.surface_text: Under the definition of District Magistrate , the special authorisation by the District Magistrate had the effect of creating officers exercising the powers of a District Magistrate under the Eviction Act. To that extent, those officers would, on authorisation, be equated to the District Magistrate. A persona designata is a person who is pointed out or described as an individual, as opposed to a person ascertained as a member of a class, or as filling a particular character.

arguments.claim: Eviction Act definition of DM relies on CrPC s.10(2) for Additional DM, unlike Requisition Act which explicitly includes them

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to the definition of District Magistrate in the United Provinces  Temporary  Accommodation Requisition Act, 1947, which includes an Additional District Magistrate . This definition has been made wide for obvious reasons, because under s. 10 2  of the Code of Criminal Procedure, the Additional District Magistrate has to be specially empowered.

holdings.text: The Additional District Magistrate was competent to grant permission under s.3 of the Eviction Act by virtue of the notification under s.10(2) CrPC investing him with all powers of District Magistrate under the Code and any other law.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, at the relevant time, provided as follows 10 1 , In every district outside the presidency, towns the Provincial Government shall appoint a Magistrate of the first class, who shall be called the District Magistrate. The Provincial Government may appoint any Magistrate of the first class to be an Additional District Magistrate and such Additional District,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification explicitly conferred all powers under CrPC and other laws; directly applies to Eviction Act permission.

holdings.text: s.10(2) CrPC applies to the Eviction Act as it is a specific provision to the contrary excluding the general s.1(2) CrPC non-interference with special laws.

anchor.surface_text: The argument overlooks the words in the absence of any specific provision to the companytrary , and because there is in the Code of Criminal Procedure such a pro. vision in s. 10 2 , sub-s.  2  of s. 1 is excluded, and an Additional District Magistrate must be regarded as possessing the powers under any other law including the Eviction Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.1(2) proviso; s.10(2) expressly empowers for other laws.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate in s.3 Eviction Act is not a persona designata; authorized officers exercise powers by virtue of office.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the District Magistrate was a persona designata cannot be accepted. Under the definition of District Magistrate , the special authorisation by the District Magistrate had the effect of creating officers exercising the powers of a District Magistrate under the Eviction Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition s.2(d) creates class of officers by office, not personal designation; distinguishes from private capacity.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate's transfer of the case to Additional District Magistrate constitutes authorization under s.2(d) Eviction Act.

anchor.surface_text: By the act of transferring the case to the Additional District Magistrate, the District Magistrate must be deemed to have authorised him to exercise his powers under s. 3 of the Eviction Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer act implies authorization to perform functions under Act; alternative ground upholding High Court.

holdings.text: The suit is competent as permission under s.3 Eviction Act was validly obtained.

anchor.surface_text: because the only point argued before us was that the suit was incompetent, because permission of the District Magistrate as required by s. 3 had number been obtained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permission valid primarily under CrPC s.10(2); suit for ejectment and damages properly decreed.
